item.title: UK looking at bespoke Afghan refugee scheme - Dominic Raab
item.description: Full details of a new resettlement scheme will be set out shortly, the foreign secretary says.

item.title: 'How many more American lives is it worth?'
item.description: "How many more American lives is it worth?" says the president, amid growing criticism over the move.

item.title: UK job vacancies at record high as wages tick up
item.description: Job vacancies hit 953,000 amid signs the country's labour market is rebounding "robustly".

item.title: Covid: PCR tests 'rip-off' and world of work 'bouncing back'
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Tuesday morning.

item.title: Snooker star Allen defeats former partner Evans
item.description: Mark Allen defeats former partner Reanne Evans 3-2 after surviving a major scare in the British Open.

item.title: No need to swap data for drinks, says privacy body
item.description: Some pub ordering apps ask too many questions, but you can refuse, says the information watchdog.

item.title: Covid testing is rip-off, says former regulator
item.description: Lord Tyrie, ex-boss of the competition watchdog, says it was slow to react to complaints about providers.

item.title: Bob Dylan denies sexually abusing girl in 1965
item.description: A woman says the US singer-songwriter abused her when she was 12 - a claim he says is untrue.

item.title: New Zealand enters nationwide lockdown over one Covid case
item.description: Authorities say they are still running tests, but are assuming it is a case of the Delta variant.

item.title: UK blood supplies to be used to make life-saving drug
item.description: Plasma from donors in England can now be used for the medicine, after a previous ban on UK supplies.

item.title: Haiti earthquake: Death toll climbs as Tropical Depression Grace hits
item.description: Tropical Depression Grace hits Haiti just days after a tremor left at least 1,419 dead.

item.title: Geronimo the alpaca gets temporary reprieve ahead of review
item.description: An application for a temporary injunction to halt his death will be considered at the High Court.

item.title: How the Taliban seized Afghanistan again
item.description: Taliban fighters have swept across Afghanistan taking control of towns and cities.

item.title: Afghanistan: Will it become haven for terror with the Taliban in power?
item.description: The Taliban are back, 20 years after being ousted for supporting terror groups. Will they do the same?

item.title: Why is the Taliban's Kabul victory being compared to the fall of Saigon?
item.description: Many have drawn parallels with America's withdrawal from Vietnam in 1975 - but is this fair?

item.title: What next for Afghanistan's economy?
item.description: Now that the Taliban are back in control of the country, can its financial system function?

item.title: How the Taliban stormed across Afghanistan in ten days
item.description: The Taliban took their first city on 6 Aug and arrived in Kabul just over a week later.

item.title: Afghanistan: Life in Kabul after the Taliban victory
item.description: BBC video journalist Malik Mudassir speaks about life in the city after its capture by the Taliban.

item.title: Afghanistan: In pictures: Kabul - a day after Taliban takeover
item.description: Kabul - the Afghan capital - is quiet in some parts, but chaotic at the airport where thousands are trying to flee.

item.title: Afghanistan: Chaotic scenes at Kabul airport
item.description: Video shows hundreds of Afghans attempting to escape, as the Taliban took over the capital.

item.title: UK military commander: 'We've betrayed' Afghans who helped British troops'
item.description: Major General Charlie Herbert, a military commander from the UK’s campaign in Afghanistan, has accused the government of betraying Afghans who supported British troops.

item.title: From a Manchester council estate to ballet dancing in Swan Lake
item.description: Isaac Bowry is from a Manchester council estate and wants to show that "dancing is for everyone".

item.title: The Papers: Race to escape Kabul 'carnage' and 'no way out'
item.description: The turmoil in Afghanistan continues to dominate the papers after the Taliban seized control of the country.

item.title: Afghanistan: UK and US must protect Afghan activists - Malala
item.description: The Nobel Peace Prize winner, who was shot by the Taliban, calls for countries to take in refugees.

item.title: Seaside entertainment skills taught to trainees
item.description: A group of young adults are being trained in seaside entertainment skills, as part of an Arts Council initiative.

item.title: Covid: Summer schools help students make up for lost time
item.description: Most of the government's summer school funding in England is being used to help Year 6s make the move to Year 7.

item.title: Images show decline of California's 'life source'
item.description: Justin Sullivan has been following California's second-largest reservoir's falling water levels.

item.title: Banksy: A guide to his 'Great British Spraycation'
item.description: New murals that have appeared on England's east coast are confirmed as the work of the elusive artist.

item.title: Otter cub found in stream 'crying for mother' rescued by RSPCA
item.description: A member of the public spotted the young mammal alone and distressed near Windermere.

item.title: Suez Canal: T. rex stuck on Ever Given arrives at golf course
item.description: The dinosaur model is finally installed at golf course after months on board the Ever Given.

item.title: Cambridgeshire sinkhole: Locals crack up at The Butts' hole
item.description: A hole in a road called The Butts causes amusement on social media after police issue a warning.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'My family is stuck and there is nothing I can do'
item.description: Afghans who have settled in the UK tell BBC News of their fears for loved ones back home.

item.title: Love and money: 'I borrowed from a friend, it went wrong'
item.description: After sleeping on the night bus with her daughter, Jo was forced to borrow money.

item.title: Afghanistan: Cardiff artist's sadness at Taliban takeover
item.description: Dan Peterson spent a month on the front line, drawing images of British soldiers and Afghan people.

item.title: Peter Karlsson: The painful verdict on Swedish ice hockey player's 1995 killing
item.description: Peter Karlsson was stabbed to death in the street. His killer said he was protecting himself - via the so-called 'gay panic' defence.

item.title: Just how hard is it to recycle a jumbo jet?
item.description: Thousands of aircraft were left on the tarmac due to Covid, and many will now be broken up for parts.

item.title: Hakainde Hichilema: The Zambian 'cattle boy' who became president
item.description: After six attempts, Hakainde Hichilema has finally become president of Zambia.

item.title: Covid: What the 'ping' rule changes mean for small businesses
item.description: What do traders in one market town make of changes to the "ping" advice?

item.title: Internet revamp for the humble landline
item.description: The UK plans to make all landlines into internet-based connections over the next few years.

item.title: Social media fraud: The influencers promoting criminal scams
item.description: BBC Panorama investigates a new generation of fraudster that openly uses social media to promote crime.

item.title: There and back again: The epic adventures of China's wandering elephants
item.description: After a mammoth journey across the country the pack of pachyderms are finally heading home.

item.title: England's women face World Cup holders NZ plus US and Canada in autumn Tests
item.description: England's women will meet World Cup holders New Zealand in back-to-back matches as the Red Roses contest four home Tests this autumn.

item.title: Murray and Watson progress at Cincinnati Masters but Evans goes out
item.description: Andy Murray wins his first singles match since pulling out of the individual event at the Olympics as he beats Richard Gasquet in Cincinnati.

item.title: England v India: India win thrilling second Test in final hour
item.description: Watch as England produce one of their worst home performances in recent memory to lose the second Test against India by 151 runs at Lord's.

item.title: England v India: Michael Vaughan says reliance on Joe Root is embarrassing
item.description: Former England captain Michael Vaughan says the team's reliance on Joe Root is embarrassing after India took the lead in the Test series with victory at Lord's.

item.title: Naomi Osaka emotional during news conference in Cincinnati
item.description: Four-time Grand Slam winner Naomi Osaka broke down in tears before resuming her first news conference since refusing to speak to media at the French Open.

item.title: Covid rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid passport: How to prove your vaccine status with the NHS Covid Pass
item.description: Fully vaccinated adults will be able to avoid self-isolation after contact with someone with Covid.

item.title: Covid: What will school be like in the new term?
item.description: Pupils across the UK are preparing to return to school after the summer holidays.

item.title: Covid: When will teenagers get the jab and do I need a booster?
item.description: More teenagers will be able to receive the Covid vaccine, and a third jab will soon be available for the most vulnerable.

item.title: Covid rules: What's changing in Wales, Scotland, England and Northern Ireland?
item.description: Lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Covid: Do I have to self-isolate if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: Self-isolation rules have now been relaxed across the UK.

item.title: UK holidays: What are the rules?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Wildfires: How Portuguese club Tondela drove through the flames
item.description: In Tondela, the bond between club and fans was at its strongest during the night in October 2017 when nobody slept.

item.title: Malta: The teenagers pulled from the sea and accused of terrorism
item.description: How three teenagers rescued from the Mediterranean Sea ended up in Malta accused of terrorism.

item.title: ‘If only I’d found out earlier I had pelvic congestion syndrome’
item.description: Sophie Robehmed suffered from back and stomach pains for years before being diagnosed with PCS.
